prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B9 Continuum: LMC late-type stars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to map the dust continuum emission of late-type stars in the LMC at band 9. Each star should be detected at approximately 5 sigma.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the default correlator configuration for the continuum mode, to obtain the optimal S/N measurements of the dust continuum.

We request an angular resolution of 0.1" to image the circumstellar envelope of evolved stars in the LMC; this will allow us to resolve extended emission in the CSE and will enable us to determine if the far-IR flux is associated with the star rather than swept-up interstellar material.
For all sources we expect the angular scale to be about 0.4" at 50 kpc. This is the median distance between the central star and the wind-ISM interaction region found by the Herschel far-infrared survey of evolved stars in the Milky Way (Cox et. al. 2012). Even for the most extreme case the maximum extent of the circumstellar envelope is expected to be less than 1.2" and thus can be observed with a single pointing of the 12m telescope.

As outlined in the science case we have selected targets detected in multiple Herschel/SPIRE bands (Seal et al. 2014, Jones et al. in prep). We have used a power-law fits to the Herschel data to compute the continuum flux for all of our targets, assuming each source is resolved with ALMA using a 0.1" PSF. We have assumed a spherical dust shell with an angular diameter of 0.4" and that the flux is spread evenly over the circumstellar shell. The predicted flux level ranges from about 3.5 mJy to 18 mJy per beam for resolved sources. We require a S/N of at least 5 to accurately measure the dust emission; if the shell has density enhancements or if the target is not resolved the S/N will be significantly higher.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 Continuum: LMC late-type stars - Point Source
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to detect the dust continuum emission of late-type stars in the LMC at band 7. Each star should be detected at approximately 5 sigma.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the default correlator configuration for the continuum mode, to obtain the optimal S/N measurements of the dust continuum.

For all our sources we expect the angular diameter to be about 0.4" at 50 kpc (Cox et al. 2012). Even for the most extreme cases, the maximum extent of the circumstellar envelope is expected to be less than 1.2" (see Groenewegen et al. 1998) and thus can be observed with a single pointing of the 12m telescope. As we do not wish to resolve the source, an angular resolution of 1" obtained using the most compact configuration, fits well with the physical size of the circumstellar envelope.

As outlined in the science case we have selected targets detected in multiple Herschel/SPIRE bands (Seal et al. 2014, Jones et al. in prep). We have used these measurements to estimate the continuum flux at 340 Ghz assuming a power law dependence on frequency. We require a S/N of at least 5.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Evolved stars are important contributors to chemical enrichment of the interstellar medium, although their contribution relative to supernovae, and how it changes with metallicity, remains uncertain. Current dust budget estimates for the Magellanic Clouds do not account for cold dust emission thus total dust-input rate may have been significantly underestimated.
Herschel observations suggest strongly that we will be able to detect the presence of cold dust around evolved stars in the LMC. However, only ALMA has the sufficient sensitivity and resolution to constrain the far-IR emission in the SED, necessary to work out the dust column density around the star. This will place exceptionally strong constrains on the global dust injection rates by late-type stars in metal-poor environments, synonymous with the early Universe.
We propose ALMA continuum observations of the 8 brightest late-type stars detected with Herschel at 350 mum to confirm the Herschel detections and to possibly resolve extended structure. If we resolve structure, it will be the first extragalatic detection of a circumstellar shell interacting with the ISM of a galaxy.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
